thread.title: Italy's Campania Wines Roll Into New York
thread.title_full: Italy's Campania Wines Roll Into New York

author: Nick Passmore
title: Italy's Campania Wines Roll Into New York
text: [caption id="attachment_3661" align="" width="1200"] Photo: Getty[/caption] Ilaria Petitto Leads An Italian Wine Revolution to New York The remarkable Ilaria Petitto of the DonnaChiara winery in Campania, despite being six months pregnant, recently led a delegation of a dozen of the region’s winemakers to New York in an effort to raise awareness of the ancient region’s wines. Despite being one of the oldest wine areas in Italy it has long been a sleepy backwater, the sort of place you would see a pig ambling along the side of a dusty road, the sort of place that produced large quantities of bulk wine nobody wanted. In this respect it’s not unlike Piedmont and Tuscany before the money and the Mercedes arrived. [caption id="attachment_3663" align="" width="1512"] Ilaria Petitto Photo: Nivk Passmore[/caption]Ilaria has a vision of changing all that, starting with her own wines. It involved a move from wine, or rather grapes, being just another agricultural product to be sold to a large producer, in this case Mastroberardino, to an emphasis on quality, to making the sorts of wines that people in Northern Europe and North America would actually want to drink. This is a radical departure for the wines of southern Italy which, in past centuries, were unlikely to make it much further than the restaurants of Naples. But it is a pattern that was started in Piedmont and Tuscany and has now spread south as Petitto is showing that it is possible to make quality wine in the rocky, sunbaked hills of Avellino, 50 km north of Naples.[caption id="attachment_3664" align="" width="1940"] DonnaChiara[/caption]And much of it is being made not with international varietals like Merlot and Chardonnay, but indigenous grapes that are showing remarkable elegance when grown and vinified employing a level of care, attention and scientific knowledge that was unheard of 30 years ago. “Everything is different today” Petitto explained. “We built the cellar with modern technologies….because we want to produce a wine in the best way we can, we want to give to our enologist all the tools to work in the best way he can.” [caption id="attachment_3675" align="" width="1216"] Cantine di Marzo[/caption]And she’s not alone, as the presence of her fellow winemakers in New York demonstrates. “In Avellino now there are so many wineries because everybody they decide to make their wine, they don’t want to sell the grapes anymore. It’s a trend.” A trend that is with real momentum – Campania is the coming region so expect to hear much more of their wines in the future. Anni Venti Greco di Tufo Spumante NV $32Greco 100%A light, fresh, unserious fizz. Perfect for a party as an alternative to the ubiquitous Prosecco. Oi Ni Campania Fiano, Tenuta Scuotto 2011 (white) $9.50Fiano 100% Rich and full-flavored, lovely with antipasto. Show’s Fiano’s ability to acquire gravitas after a few years in the bottle. Greco di Tufo, Contea de Altavila 2013 (white) $11Greco 100% Aromatic woody flavors mingle with honeyed lemon in this intriguing, inexpensive white. Le Tre Rose di Gio Falanghina 2014, Tenute Biancino (white) $6Falanghina Here this ancient grape of Campania shows a distinct, Viognier-like floral quality along with its trademark earthy rusticality. La Loggia del Cavalieri Riserva 2008, Tenuta Cavalier Pepe (red) $20Aglianico 100%Earthy but retaining a nimble freshness and perfect for red meats. A charming wine. Taurasi 2010, Macchie S. Maria (red) $9.50Aglianico 100%A serious, structured wine and quite superb for the price. Taurasi 2011, Donnachiara (red) $40Aglianico 100% A gorgeous combination of volcanic minerality prettied up with tantalizing hints of violets, rosemary and wild mountain thyme. Will improve for at least another five years.
